Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Bluebird: Integrated Internet-of-Things for Education
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project will develop an easy to use internet-of-things (IoT) platform, called "Bluebird", for use in K-12 Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math (STEM) education. This project will employ a craft-oriented approach to STEM education, which breaks down gender barriers and engages students from diverse backgrounds. It is estimated that 65% of primary school children will grow up to work in jobs that do not yet exist. This new workforce will be the result of what is being referred to as the "fourth industrial revolution", brought on by a fusion of technologies in the physical, digital, and biological spheres. The goal of this project is to develop an ecosystem of IoT technologies that prepare students for these industries. The platform to be developed will disrupt the current commercial landscape by providing an affordable and student-friendly alternative to devices which are either expensive or overly challenging for beginners to adopt. The resulting product platform will serve the global smart education and learning market, which is expected to grow to $586 billion by 2021.

The intellectual merit of this project is to develop a "smart" education tool that will enable educators and learners to control the ways in which technology shapes their lives. This innovation will eliminate the major hurdles that create conceptual, practical, and economic barriers for students to gain literacy of information networks and human-centered design. To achieve this goal, the team will research and develop a platform and an easy-to-use device that overcomes the technical challenges of providing IoT experiences in the classroom, where wireless internet is often unreliable, and the security and privacy of students must be safeguarded. The key objectives for this project are 1) to develop a classroom-ready framework for IoT including curriculum that adheres to educational mandates; 2) to design and build low-cost and low-power hardware, firmware, and protocols for the platform; and 3) to design and implement a mobile application to facilitate communications and programming. The anticipated result of this research is a platform that provides K-12 classroom access to IoT tools and skills. The design and manufacture of this project opens up a new market as Bluebird users craft their own IoT ideas, products, and services.

POR.DRECONTENT:
For this SBIR Phase 1 project, Teknikio has developed a classroom-ready framework for Educators' and Learners' Internet of Things (ELIoT). Our technical goals at the start of the project were as follows:

1) To design and build a low-cost, low-power Bluetooth hardware “Bluebird”, firmware and protocols, integrating with multiple devices

2) To design and implement the Teknest Application platform to facilitate the Bluebird communications and programming

3) To design and implement the ELIoT platform and the interface that allows communication over the Internet with controlled access to third-party services.

Our team was able to successfully fulfill all of these objectives by the completion of this project. We have created a low-cost, accessible framework for beginners to start prototyping Internet-of-Things projects that is robust enough for a classroom environment and lends itself to many applications in STEM education. We developed 4 iterations of the Bluebird hardware and an iOS Application for our custom block-coding language which is available for download through the Apple App Store, and conducted several user testing sessions.

The system was tested internationally with educators and students from K12 schools, museums, and universities. We also held focus groups to educators to generate feedback and ideas for how the system could be improved and expanded, especially for a dynamic setting like a museum. Educators expressed that our software was extremely user friendly and an engaging alternative to more complex alternatives. They were particularly excited by the audio and communication features and self-directed interaction within the App. We taught a 12 week class by the title of Wireless Toys to undergraduate and graduate students at Parsons, the New School of Design, using Bluebird as the primary toolset. Students were able to build complete prototypes of smart toys by combining Bluebird with everyday materials such as cardboard, fabric, and wood. Students appreciated the ease of setup of our tool and the ability to combine with other electronic components, especially for a school project were they had limited time and resources.

Our ELIoT system will have a wide impact around K12 STEM education by providing an easy-to-use platform that fosters creative confidence, engages girls in making and coding thus dissolving the gender imbalance in STEM and offers a highly collaborative platform for students and teachers. At the end of Phase 1 of this project we are confident that we have created a powerful future-forward learning tool  that will be competitive in the educational technology product landscape for middle and high school classrooms.
